0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-canada-idUSKBN1340I9	Some Americans look to Canada
column2: NZ as Trump surges to victory	"

column1: By Jeffrey Hodgson and Charlotte Greenfield
| TORONTO/WELLINGTON

TORONTO/WELLINGTON Canada's main immigration website remained down on Wednesday and New Zealand reported increased traffic to its website for residency visas from U.S. nationals as Donald Trump surged to victory in the U.S. presidential election.Americans have often vowed to leave the country if their chosen candidate doesn't win the election
column2: but this time around some are actually preparing to do so after Trump stunningly won the Nov. 8 election.A spokeswoman for Canada's immigration department said the website crashed ""as a result of a significant increase in the volume of traffic"" as election results rolled in Tuesday night.Bonnie Quinn
column3: a New Jersey insurance underwriter planning to move to Canada with her husband said she felt ""just downright embarrassed"" by the election results.""I'm not sure in what order we should do things - find jobs first or move
column4: said Quinn
column6: whose Irish grandparents once immigrated to Canada.In New Zealand
column7: immigration officials said the New Zealand Now website
column8: which deals with residency and student visas
column10: 593 registrations from United States citizens since Nov. 1 - more than 50 percent of a typical month's registrations in just seven days. Rod Drury
column11: the chief executive of NZ-based global accounting software firm Xero
column12: said the statistics matched up with interest his company has been seeing from prospective U.S. national employees concerned about a Trump win.

column1: Drury said what started as a joke was becoming a reality. ""I've got lots of messages coming through at the moment asking for a job in New Zealand
column2: and we're saying 'Yes you can'
column3: Drury told Reuters by telephone on Wednesday.In the hours after Trump's victory
column4: Americans were searching for jobs in Canada at 10 times the rate of previous nights
column6: chief economist for job website Indeed.""It's far too soon to guess how many of these searchers will make a move after the shock wears off. But the jump in searches shows how many Americans were surprised by Trump's victory and are thinking about their options elsewhere
column7: Kolko said in an emailed statement.

column1: In Atlanta
column2: business coach Nancy Chorpenning
column4: said she and her husband are looking to move to Costa Rica sooner than their planned retirement because of the Trump victory.""I am simply terrified the new administration and Congress may destroy the Social Security we count on when my husband retires
column6: who is traveling to Costa Rica next week to scout for condos.After some Americans
column8: said they would move to Canada if Trump was elected
column9: the idea was taken up by some Canadian communities.

column1: In February
column2: the island of Cape Breton on Canada's Atlantic coast marketed itself as a tranquil refuge for Americans seeking to escape should Trump capture the White House.On Maple Match
column3: a recently-launched dating website aimed to match Americans fleeing Trump with Canadians
column4: users have more than doubled to about 14
column6: according to chief executive Joe Goldman.While the pledge to ""move to Canada"" has been made in elections past
column8: although thousands of Americans who opposed the Vietnam War moved to Canada.Migration data from after Republican George W. Bush's 2000 election and 2004 re-election - other moments when liberal Americans pledged to move to Canada in protest - suggest few followed through on their promises. While immigration to Canada increased during the years of Bush's elections
column9: the rise was not more than increases in other years
column10: data from the Montreal-based Association for Canadian Studies show. (Additional reporting by Andrea Hopkins in Ottawa
column12: writing by Jane Wardell in WELLINGTON; Editing by Martin Howell and Alan Crosby)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-pharmaceuticals-idUSKBN134120	California voters turn down drug pricing initiative	"
By Deena Beasley
| LOS ANGELES

LOS ANGELES California voters turned down a ballot initiative aimed at reining in rising prices for prescription drugs after pharmaceutical companies spent more than $100 million to fight it.The California Drug Price Relief Act
column2: also known as Proposition 61
column3: sought to limit state health programs from paying more for medications than the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs (VA)
column4: which receives the steepest discounts in the country. As of Wednesday morning
column5: with more than 99 percent of precincts partially reporting from Tuesday's election
column6: the vote was 46 percent in favor of the measure and 54 percent opposed
column7: according to California's Secretary of State.""The pharmaceutical companies spent a lot to defeat this
column9: professor of health policy and management at the University of California
column10: Los Angeles Fielding School of Public Health. ""They wanted to draw a line in the sand.""The measure's defeat ""reaffirms the power of the biopharma lobby
column11: Jefferies analyst Brian Abrahams said in a note to investors on Wednesday.

column1: The rising cost of prescription drugs came under attack during the U.S. presidential campaign. Both President-elect Donald Trump and Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton called for cost-trimming measures including allowing Medicare
column2: the federal health plan for seniors
column3: to negotiate prices with drugmakers.Shares in pharmaceutical and biotechnology shares
column4: under pressure in recent weeks
column5: soared on Wednesday as market fears of a win by Clinton and Democrats gaining power in Congress receded. The Nasdaq Biotechnology index .NBI advanced 7 percent and was on track for its biggest single-day gain in about five years.    Proposition 61's opponents
column6: led by global drugmakers such as Pfizer Inc and Amgen Inc
column7: spent around $106 million. They argued that it would benefit only 12 percent of Californians
column10: at risk of higher drug costs.

column1: Supporters
column2: led by the AIDS Healthcare Foundation and AARP
column3: which advocates for seniors
column4: said only drug companies themselves can raise prices for veterans or other consumers. Vermont Independent Senator Bernie Sanders also campaigned in support of Proposition 61
column5: calling on voters to ""stand up to the greed of the pharmaceutical industry.""Proponents
column6: who raised $17 million to support the initiative
column7: estimated it could save California taxpayers up to $5.7 billion over 10 years
column8: although a state legislative analysis said the financial impact is not clear.UCLA's Schweitzer said the measure would have had only a modest impact on state drug costs.

column1: There were also questions about how Proposition 61 would be implemented. The VA's mandated prices are listed publicly
column2: but its steepest negotiated price discounts are required by law to be confidential.The VA spends some $6.1 billion a year on medicines for 6 million veterans. Proposition 61 would have extended those discounts to around 4.5 million Californians
column3: including certain members of the state's low-income Medicaid plan
column4: state employees and retirees
column5: university teachers and prisoners.A similar proposition has been approved for Ohio's 2017 November ballot.  (Reporting By Deena Beasley; Editing by Mary Milliken and Grant McCool)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-whitehouse-transition-idUSKBN1343D1	Obama intends to brief
column2: not lobby
column3: Trump on policies: White House	"

column1: WASHINGTON President Barack Obama intends to brief
column2: rather than lobby
column3: President-elect Donald Trump about the Obama administration's policies during the transition of power
column4: the White House said on Wednesday.Speaking at a news briefing
column5: White House spokesman Josh Earnest added
column7: that viewing some policies from inside the government ""gives you a new appreciation for the benefits of those policies.""

column1: President Obama is committed to an effective transition that helps bring President-elect Trump and his team up to speed on the current status of U.S. policy
column2: including foreign policy
column3: Earnest said.

column1: (Reporting by Sussan Heavey; Writing by Mohammad Zargham; Editing by Chris Reese)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-senate-new-hampshire-idUSKBN1343BV	Democrat Hassan wins New Hampshire Senate race	"
BOSTON New Hampshire Governor Maggie Hassan
column2: a Democrat
column3: has been elected to the U.S. Senate
column4: ousting incumbent Republican Kelly Ayotte
column5: the New Hampshire secretary of state confirmed on Wednesday.Hassan won by a narrow margin
column9: according to a final tally posted online on Wednesday.

column1: It will be my job in the U.S. Senate to make the best decisions for New Hampshire to work with President-elect Trump when it is in the best interest of New Hampshire and the country
column2: and to stand up to him when it isn't
column3: Hassan said.

column1: (Reporting by Scott Malone; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama and Jonathan Oatis)"
4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-slovenia-trump-idUSKBN1342BF	Melania's Slovenian hometown eyes Trump win as boon for tourism	"
By Gasper Lubej
| SEVNICA
column2: Slovenia

column1: SEVNICA
column2: Slovenia The small Slovenian town of Sevnica
column3: Melania Trump's birthplace
column4: savored her husband's shock win in the U.S. election as a likely boon for tourism on Wednesday
column5: while a former schoolmate remembered her as ""creative and innovative"".Until about a year ago
column8: nestled in the foothills of the Alps
column10: let alone abroad.  But on Monday
column11: Sevnica was clearly looking forward to a financial spin-off from being the hometown of the 46-year-old future U.S. First Lady.""Sometimes the pressure of the media was too hard. The people of Sevnica are not used to it. On the other hand
column12: the global attention is positive because Sevnica is developing into a tourist destination
column13: mayor Srecko Ocvirk said.Speaking to Reuters shortly after 7 a.m. (0600 GMT) in Sevnica's Central cafe
column14: the smiling mayor said local residents had supported Trump and his wife's campaign.

column1: We are very satisfied at the result
column2: he said.Born Melania Knavs in 1970
column3: she lived in an apartment block in Sevnica with her family as a child. When she was a teenager
column4: the family moved to a modest two-storey house above the Sava river on the outskirts of town
column5: which sits below a well-maintained medieval castle.Residents say her father sold car parts and her mother worked for a factory that made a brand of children's clothing very popular in communist Yugoslavia
column6: before the country fell apart in the 1990s.

column1: Melania's modeling career took her to Milan and thence to the United States
column2: far away from her native Slovenia
column3: a tiny former Yugoslav republic of 2 million people comparable in size to New Jersey.""Even as a child Melania was creative
column4: innovative and Sevnica was too small for her
column6: Melania's friend who is now a headmistress of Melania's elementary school.

column1: She was reserved and when I heard that Donald was running I said (to myself) this will be hard for her. She never wanted to be in the spotlight
column2: Jelancic said. ""She was excellent at her job (in the campaign).""The head of the town's health center
column3: which received a donation from Melania in 2005 when she was pregnant with her son Barron
column4: said she believed Melania would be a success in the White House
column5: as well.""Melania will be an excellent First Lady who will take Slovenian values of generosity
column6: loyalty and trust to the United States and the world
column7: Vladimira Tomsic said.   (Reporting by Gasper Lubej; Writing by Marja Novak; editing by Justyna Pawlak and Richard Balmforth)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-whitehouse-idUSKBN13439C	White House says committed to implementing Iran deal
column2: climate change agreement	"

column1: WASHINGTON The Obama administration remains committed to implementing the Paris agreement on climate change and the Iran nuclear deal through its final months
column2: the White House said on Wednesday after the presidential election victory of Republican Donald Trump.""This administration will be committed to implementing those policies through January 20th
column3: and we will live up to the  commitments that we have made in each of those areas as we do so
column4: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said at a news briefing.

column1: Trump
column2: who strongly criticized the Iran deal and the Paris agreement
column3: will start his four-year term on Jan. 20.

column1: (Reporting by Susan Heavey; Writing by Mohammad Zargham; Editing by David Alexander)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ecb-latvia-idUSKBN13438G	ECB's Rimsevics says Trump will be 'very good' president	"
RIGA European Central Bank ratesetter Ilmars Rimsevics welcomed Donald Trump's U.S. presidential election win on Wednesday
column2: saying the Republican would be a ""very good"" president. ""I think that he will be a very good president because he has to prove that he will bring about some change and... structural reforms
column3: Rimsevics said during a TV interview.

column1: (Reporting By Gederts Gelzis; Writing by Francesco Canepa in Frankfurt; editing by John Stonestreet)"
7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-congress-idUSKBN13317Z	Republicans defend grip on U.S. Congress as Trump wins presidency	"
By Richard Cowan and Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Republicans maintained their majorities in both chambers of the U.S. Congress in a momentous election on Tuesday in which Republican Donald Trump won the presidency
column2: empowering the party to reshape Washington.The Republican sweep sets up the United States for two years of ""unified"" government
column3: which would normally mean significant policy change
column4: although Trump's election was anything but normal and he will start his presidency with unusual handicaps. Both Republican leaders on Capitol Hill held Trump at arm's length during the campaign. Trump offended and attacked some congressional Republicans on the stump
column5: including House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan.Early on Wednesday
column6: shortly after Clinton conceded to Trump
column7: Ryan said in a statement: ""We are eager to work hand-in-hand with the new administration to advance an agenda to improve the lives of the American people.""Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell
column9: said in a guarded and similarly timed statement: ""The American people have chosen a new direction for our nation.""The new Congress will not convene until Jan. 3
column10: but the ""lame-duck"" Congress will return next week and Republicans are set to begin the process of picking leaders for both chambers.Ryan's position as speaker could be challenged by Republican conservatives who backed Trump and it remains to be seen if the president-elect himself will try to push Ryan out.""Trump seems magnanimous right now
column11: an aide to one of Trump's House supporters said after Trump stressed unity in his victory speech in New York. ""We shall see.""In a huge disappointment to Democrats
column12: Republicans were on a pace to lose only a handful of seats in the House
column13: well below the double-digit losses some predicted.Similarly
column14: Democrats gained only one seat in the Senate
column15: although a few races were still to be determined
column17: where incumbent Republican Kelly Ayotte was deadlocked with Democrat Maggie Hassan early on Wednesday.

column1: In Illinois
column2: Democratic U.S. Representative Tammy Duckworth defeated Republican Senator Mark Kirk. Democrats needed to pick up a net five seats to win Senate control.PREDICTIONS DEFIED

column1: Republican successes came on the heels of big Republican gains in the 2014 congressional elections and defied predictions the party was in tatters and on the verge of splitting apart because of deep divisions over Trump.Congressional Republicans are sure to flex their muscles on a range of legislation
column2: not the least of which is fulfilling a six-year quest to repeal President Barack Obama's landmark healthcare law known as ""Obamacare.""

column1: Republicans also campaigned on an agenda that shunned comprehensive immigration reform and opposed gun control and expanded environmental and financial regulations.In the Senate
column2: McConnell
column3: a Kentucky Republican
column4: was expected to remain at his post for at least the next two years.Paul Sracic
column5: who chairs the politics department at Youngstown State University in Ohio
column6: said: ""There was all this concern that Trump would damage Republicans down-ticket. Just the opposite happened"" as Trump brought out more Republican voters.Come January
column7: Republicans will have to pivot from trying to block Obama's initiatives - such as his signature health insurance program Obamacare - to governing along with Trump.""Republicans no longer have the luxury of being the opposition party
column9: a political science professor at George Washington University.

column1: For example
column2: will they actually repeal Obamacare and agree what to implement in its place?"" she added.MCCONNELL'S PAYOFF

column1: McConnell led conservatives' opposition to any Supreme Court nominee named by Obama following last February's death of conservative Justice Antonin Scalia.His gamble paid off and he will now await a nomination from Trump
column2: likely dooming Obama's choice of federal judge Merrick Garland.Star-power incumbent Republicans
column3: such as Senator John McCain in Arizona and Marco Rubio in Florida
column4: also scored victories. Issues ranging from tax cuts to border security will now take center stage in Washington. Trump's opposition to trade deals with foreign countries puts in serious jeopardy the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement negotiated by Obama that would cover economies from Japan to Chile.""In terms of trade
column5: I think TPP is dead. The stake went through its heart tonight
column6: Sracic said. (Additional reporting by Ian Simpson; Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-congress-ryan-idUSKBN1342YY	Speaker Ryan pledges to work with Trump on bold agenda	"
By David Morgan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan
column2: who sparred with Donald Trump at times during his presidential campaign
column3: pledged on Wednesday to work closely with the president-elect to forge an aggressive Republican legislative agenda from the outset of 2017.At a news conference in his hometown of Janesville
column4: Wisconsin
column5: Ryan said he and Trump are arranging a meeting to discuss the transition to a new Congress and administration
column6: as well as the Republican agenda for the lame-duck session of Congress that begins on Monday.Tuesday's election results will give the Republicans simultaneous control of the White House
column7: Senate and House for the first time since early 2007.""He just earned a mandate and we now just have a unified Republican government
column8: Ryan said of Trump. ""The opportunity is now here. And the opportunity is to go big
column9: to go bold and to get things done.""Ryan said he expected his six-point ""A Better Way"" blueprint to provide a framework for future action. The plan
column10: which House Republicans used an election platform
column11: calls for initiatives that include repealing and replacing Obamacare
column12: reforming the U.S. tax code and scaling back federal regulations on industry.

column1: Ryan had been slow to endorse Trump for president and clashed with the wealthy businessman over his incendiary campaign rhetoric
column2: accusing him of making comment that was ""the textbook definition of racism"" about a judge of Mexican heritage. Last month Trump described Ryan as ""a very weak and ineffective leader.""But on Wednesday Ryan said he and Trump had held two ""fantastic conversations"" in the past 18 hours. Ryan's aim is to ""make sure that when his hand comes off the Bible
column3: when he is sworn in as president
column4: we are hitting the ground running.""

column1: Ryan said Republicans in Congress also would coordinate with Trump on the upcoming lame duck session on what can be achieved. The speaker also said it was time for ""redemption
column2: not recrimination"" and dismissed concerns about civil liberties created by Trump campaign talk.""Donald Trump heard a voice out in this country that no one else heard. He connected in ways with people no one else did. He turned politics on its head
column3: Ryan said.

column1: Donald Trump provided the kind of coattails that got a lot of people over the finish line so that we could maintain our strong House and Senate majorities.""There had been speculation Ryan would not run for the speaker job in January but last week his staff said he would run for re-election to the post. (Reporting by David Morgan and Julia Edwards Ainsley; Editing by Bill Trott)"
9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-netanyahu-idUSKBN13437J	Trump invites Netanyahu to meeting 'at the first opportunity': Israel	"
JERUSALEM Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke to newly elected U.S. President Donald Trump by phone on Wednesday and Trump invited him to a meeting ""at the first opportunity""
column2: Netanyahu's office said.The conversation was ""hearty and warm"" and regional issues were discussed
column3: the office said
column4: adding: ""The Prime Minister congratulated Trump on his electoral win and told him that the United States has no better ally than Israel.""

column1: (Writing by Ori Lewis; editing by John Stonestreet)"
